abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the On-Farm Irrigation
            Project for Kyrgyz Republic were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: good construction supervision work is
            essential for satisfactory outcome. In particular, strict
            supervision for quality of works is required and
            disqualification of non-performing contractors should be
            applied. Another lesson is that institution strengthening is
            a long process and should be given enough resources, regular
            coaching, expertise, and, above all, time. It also requires
            institutional support to the Water Users Association (WUA)
            process to be embodied in government institutions in order
            to secure its sustainability. WUA command areas should be
            seen as a single unit from the water management improvement
            point-of-view. Much attention should be paid to requirements
            of regulatory structures such as intakes, division boxes,
            culverts, outlets, cross regulators, energy dissipaters, and
            flow meters, which will allow WUAs to distribute water among
            member farmers in a more reliable and timely manner. On-farm
            canal lining, which is expensive, should be used only for
            those sections of the system where it will be technically
            required to reduce high seepage losses.

repnme.cdata!:
Water user associations as an essential
            component of irrigation reform : Kyrgyz Republic's
            first and second on-farm irrigation projects

abstracts.cdata!:
With the collapse of the Soviet Union
            and the subsequent independence of the Kyrgyz Republic in
            1991, the country's agricultural sector experienced a
            serious crisis. Due to a deterioration of organizational
            structures in the state and collective farms, a large
            reduction in subsidies, and shifts in relative prices for
            outputs and inputs, agricultural production declined
            significantly. The rapidly deteriorating irrigation and
            drainage systems further reduced agricultural output.
            Despite the complex situation, irrigated agriculture,
            together with livestock, continued in the 1990s to be a
            major component in the Kyrgyz Republic's economy,
            accounting for 45 percent of GDP on average as well as 43
            percent of employment. The next step was to rehabilitate and
            modernize on-farm irrigation infrastructure within the
            former large farms so that the supplied water could be used
            more efficiently. To ensure adequate maintenance afterwards,
            the government sought to promote the development and
            strengthening of water users associations (WUAs) as the
            critical organization responsible for on-farm irrigation
            operation and maintenance. Support to the government to
            address these sector issues was provided under the On-Farm
            Irrigation Project (Project I), and is being continued under
            the Second On-Farm Irrigation Project (Project II).

            first and second on-farm irrigation projects

repnme.cdata!: Kyrgyz Republic - On - Farm Irrigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The On-Farm Irrigation Project will
            achieve increased crop production, through reliable, and
            sustainable water distribution on irrigated land across the
            Kyrgyz Republic. The components will: 1) support the
            establishment, and training of water users
            associations' (WUAs) units at the Department of Water
            Resources central office, and its offices in the seven
            oblasts selected under the project. Technical expertise will
            be provided for WUA development, through formal, and
            on-the-job raining; 2) support rehabilitation of on-farm
            irrigation distribution systems under the management of
            WUAs, giving priority to farms within the area of irrigation
            systems that have, or will be rehabilitated under the
            Irrigation Rehabilitation Project (IRP); and, 3) strengthen
            the Project Implementation Unit, established for
            implementation of the IRP, and the Flood Emergency Project,
            with the necessary staff, and equipment to implement this
            project as well. Auditing expenses will be financed from the Credit.
